TF053109-GEF3 PDFB-BHUTAN:MULTI-SECTORAL

            LAND MANAGEMENT PROJECT

abstracts.cdata!:
The Sustainable Land Management Project
            for Bhutan had a satisfactory outcome, with the performances
            of the Bank as well as the borrower being satisfactory. Most
            of the project development objectives (PDO) indicators and
            the global environment objectives (GEO) indicators have been
            achieved either completely, or to a large extent. This paper
            pertains to the provision of a grant for the aforementioned
            project. Significant lessons learned during the
            implementation of the project are: 1) the project design in
            terms of multi-sectoral approach and phase-wise
            implementation models worked well and did not show any signs
            of serious weaknesses; 2) the participatory Sustainable Land
            Management (SLM) action planning methodology proved to be an
            excellent approach for community-based planning of SLM,
            enhancing community commitment and ownership, facilitating
            inclusion of local knowledge in decision-making and
            participation of all households including women; 3) the
            participatory approach created a conducive environment for
            allowing communities to work together and build social
            capital, thus contributing to mainstreaming gender, ensuring
            equity and improvement of livelihoods of the poor; 4) the
            SLM implementation was hampered by the remoteness of rural
            communities, and associated difficulties; and 5) the lack of
            labor availability due to rural-urban migration at the
            household level is a key constraint in adoption and
            successful implementation of project interventions.
